qas.question: Who suggested that the Free Trade Agreement amounted to an American takeover of Canada?
Who erased the border in the ad?
What was the slogan of this ad?
Who suggested that the Progressive Conservative amounted to an American takeover of Canada?
When was the campaign to run ads of a map of Progressive Conservatives run?
Who erased the border in political parties?
What was the slogan of this takeover?
Who asserted that the proposed Canada-US border amounted to an American permanent marker?

context: The phrase is usually used in local political debates, in polemic writing or in private conversations. It is rarely used by politicians themselves in a public context, although at certain times in Canadian history political parties have used other similarly loaded imagery. <a1_0><b5_0>In the 1988 federal election<b5_0/><a1_0/>, the <a0_0><b4_0><b8_0>Liberals<b8_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> asserted that the proposed Free Trade Agreement amounted to an American takeover of Canada—notably, the party ran an ad in which <a2_0><b6_0>Progressive Conservative (PC) strategists<b6_0/><a2_0/>, upon the adoption of the agreement, slowly erased the Canada-U.S. border from a desktop map of North America. Within days, however, the PCs responded with an ad which featured the border being drawn back on with a permanent marker, as an announcer intoned <a3_0><b7_0>"Here's where we draw the line."
